prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (2021) proposed a multi-layer network in Physica A 564, where each social layer is shown in Figure 2. The nodes in the network represent people, with weighted connections indicating social contact that could lead to infection based on the edge weight (a probability value between 0 and 1). The first layer depicts home interactions comprising groups of varying sizes, which are internally fully connected. These groups are isolated from external connections, symbolizing individual families. The distribution of family sizes in Argentina in 2009 was used to create these groups, with probabilities of family sizes between 1 and 10 considered. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . In every country, a significant portion of the population engages in some form of work or economic activity, leading to interactions with others. This makes work a crucial factor in social relationships, especially during an epidemic. To model work activity, we propose a generic layer that connects individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of the total population in Argentina. Due to the diverse job market, creating a connection rule that accurately reflects real-world relationships is complex. We suggest a common scenario with random group sizes ranging from 5 to 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected.  This layer, shown in Fig. 2(b) for n = 100, emphasizes the importance of edge weights in virus transmission discussed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is vital in urban areas but poses a risk for epidemics due to high population density and frequent movement. The third layer in our model represents public transport users, accounting for around 50% of the population on average, with group sizes varying from 10 to 40. This inclusion aims to capture the dynamics of virus spread in crowded environments like buses and trains.
original_pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 Fig. 2. Each social layer of the proposed multi-layer network. The nodes are people and do not change across layers, and the weighted connections represent social contact which may lead to infection according to the edge weight (probability value within [0, 1)). The first layer represents home interactions and is composed of a set of groups with varying sizes, which are fully connected internally. These groups have no external connections, i.e., the network starts with disconnected components representing each family. To create each group, we consider the Brazilian family size distribution for 2010 [22], the year with more detailed information on family sizes from 1 up to 14 members. We consider the probability of a family having sizes from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
original_post_context: . A large fraction of the population in any country need to work or practice some kind of economic activity, which means interacting with other people. Thus, work represents one of the most important factors of social relations, which is also very important in an epidemic scenario. To represent the work activity, we propose a generic layer to connect people with ages from 18 to 59 years, i.e., 60% of the total population in the case of Brazil. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using n = 100. Although the nodes of a group are fully connected, the transmission of the virus depends directly on the edge weights, which we discuss in-depth on Section 3.1.1. Collective transports are essential in most cities but are among the most crowded environments and play an important role in an epidemic scenario due to the possibility of geographical spread, as vehicles are constantly moving around. The third layer we propose represents these public transports that include people who do not possess or use a personal vehicle. In Brazil the number of people using public transport depends on the size of the city, with 64.98% in the capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], with an average use of around 1.2 h a day.1 Here we consider the average of the population between the two cases (50%), randomly sampled, to participate in the ''transports'' layer. Random groups are created with sizes between [10, 40], uniformly sampled, and the nodes within each group are fully connected. This variation of sizes 1 http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-brasil/noticia/2015/02/brasileiros-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html. 5

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. examined the impact of various interventions on the course of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospital occupancy. The infection initially begins at a node with a degree close to the network average and spreads over 300 days in daily iterations. The study considers an optimistic scenario in which individuals are aware of the virus from the start, leading to a lower initial infection probability (β < 1) due to natural social distancing practices. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine is implemented to simulate measures taken by Argentinian states like Buenos Aires on March 24. This quarantine involves reducing contacts in certain areas to 30% of their initial levels (β = 0.09). The impact of the β parameter on the epidemic shape is analyzed, showing that higher infection rates lead to faster spread and more cases and deaths, but also to quicker end of the epidemic due to natural immunization.

4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model shows a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The increase in diagnosed cases in the last ten days could be due to more testing in Argentina or the consistently low isolation levels (below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. We assumed a fixed isolation level based on the early days after government decrees in Argentina, but data suggests these levels are fluctuating. This could lead to higher numbers of cases and deaths in future simulations (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). The average daily death toll in our models is higher than official figures, likely due to underdetection rates and limited testing. Analysis of deaths in Argentina from January to April indicate a significant rise after the first confirmed case of COVID-19 on February 26, suggesting the actual death toll may be much higher than reported. Looking ahead, after 90 days (May 26), possible actions include maintaining current isolation levels, returning to normal activities, only resuming work activities, or increasing isolation further by halting work and transport activities.
original_pre_context: eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 the effects of different actions on the overall epidemic picture, such as the increase and reduction of cases, deaths, and occupied beds in hospitals. The social network starts with all its layers and the original infection probabilities. The infection begins at a node with the closest degree to the average network degree and propagates at iterations of 1 day (up to 300 days). We consider an optimistic scenario in which people are aware of the virus since the beginning, thus the initial infection probability is β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e., β = 0.09. The remaining activities on these layers represent services that could not be stopped, such as essential services, activities that are kept taking higher precautionary measures and disrespecting the quarantine. Under this scenario, we first analyze how the β parameter impacts the overall epidemic shape. Fig. 4(a) shows results for 4 β values in function of daily new cases and deaths, iterating from up to 300 days after the first infection. As higher the infection rates, faster is the disease spreading and the final number of cases and deaths. On the other hand, the epidemic ends faster due to natural immunization of recovered nodes. 4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Brazilian epidemic (up to May 18) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
original_post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model achieves a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be related to the increase in Brazil's tests. Or yet, the constant decrease of isolation levels in the country (below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. We considered here a fixed isolation level around what was observed in the first days after the government decrees in Brazil. Still, data from the same reference show that these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths for the remaining simulation may be higher than the reported on this paper (see the ''keep isolation'' scenario in the next section). Concerning the daily death toll, the average number of the proposed models is higher than that of the official numbers. This is somehow expected, considering that the underdetection rates may be higher in contrast to the fewer number of tests being performed. To better understand this, we analyzed the number of death in Brazil from January 1 to April 30, comparing cases between 2019 and 2020; the results are shown in Fig. 5. It is possible to observe a clear increasing pattern after February 26, which is the day of the first officially confirmed case of COVID-19 in Brazil, indicating that the real death toll may be significantly higher than the official numbers. 4.2. Future actions and its impacts After the initial epidemic phase, we consider four possible actions that can be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Do nothing more, maintaining the current isolation levels; b) Stop isolation, returning activities to normal (initial network layers and weights); c) Return only work activities, restoring the initial probability of the layer; or d) Increase isolation, stopping the remaining activities in work and transport

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 shows the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization under three scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) Maintaining current isolation measures (no schools or religious gatherings, reduced work and transport), (b) Ending isolation (returning schools, religious gatherings, work, and transport to normal), or (c) Increasing isolation (halting work and public transport). Due to limitations in testing capacity - either due to a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus - only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the initial isolation measures were put in place, halting schools and religious activities while work and transportation continued at 30% capacity. This was achieved by further reducing the β term. Different options were then considered 90 days after the first case: maintaining the current isolation levels, increasing isolation, lifting isolation entirely and returning to 100% activity, or only returning work activities. Results showed that maintaining current isolation levels would lead to prolonged spread, nearing the estimated peak around June 5 with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1,900 daily deaths, totaling 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths by year's end. Hospitals may exceed capacity by June 11, but efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper patient logistics could help control the situation. However, this is a hopeful scenario assuming that social isolation levels remain above 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentine quarantine. Currently, Argentina's social isolation levels are consistently at 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers analyzed three scenarios for the progression of infected and recovered COVID-19 cases along with hospital bed utilization. The scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, lifting isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Due to limited testing capacity, only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were considered in the analysis. Asymptomatic cases were not diagnosed and continued to interact within the network. Assumptions were made that mild cases would self-isolate at home if aware of their symptoms and severe or critical cases would be hospitalized and isolated. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and
post_context: until the end of the year. In this case, hospitals could reach their maximum capacity by June 11. But, by efficiently adding new ICU beds and effectively managing patient logistics, the situation may still be manageable. However, this is a optimistic assumption, based on our criteria for "maintaining isolation" which requires a social isolation rate of over 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentine quarantine [43]. Currently, Argentina's social isolation level remains at just 12%.

post_context: : According to the position statement released by the National Centre of Disease Control Malaysia [21], a person remains infectious for up to 11 days after first contracting COVID-19.With a δ value of 1/5, the SARS-CoV2 virus typically has an incubation period of around 5 days. The α value, which is 0.000064, represents the fatality rate as the percentage of deaths among all previously infected individuals. In Malaysia, at the time of this study, there were 26 deaths out of a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. The ρ value of 1/9 is used for analysis purposes as the average time for recovery or death from COVID-19, but due to variations in different demographics and unpredictability, an accurate average cannot be obtained. Moving on to the results and discussion section, the dynamics of the delay in compulsory mask wearing were analyzed using SEIR models for three scenarios. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, simulations were done to determine the Maximum Infected Values for different delays in mask enforcement. The results showed that earlier enforcement of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also lengthens the time taken to reach it. This is indicated by a shift to the right of the peak of the Infected compartment curve and a lower peak value. The infected numbers increase until they reach a global maximum before starting to decrease, which is in line with compartmental models.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
According to the National Centre of Disease Control Malaysia, individuals with COVID-19 remain infectious for up to 11 days, while the SARS-CoV2 virus has an incubation period of approximately 5 days. The fatality rate, defined as the percentage of deaths among previously infected individuals, is 0.000064. Due to significant variation in this rate across demographics and the low number of deaths in Malaysia, an accurate average cannot be calculated. Therefore, for analysis purposes, a rate of 1/9 (9 days) is used. 
In the study's results and discussion, the SEIR models were applied to three scenarios to simulate the impact of delaying compulsory mask-wearing. The analysis showed the maximum infected values under different delay scenarios, with the most basic case showing the effect of mask enforcement on the day of the first COVID-19 case in Malaysia, after 50 days, after 100 days, and not enforced at all. From Figure 3, it can be deduced that earlier enforcement of mask wearing both reduces the Maximum Infected Value as well as increases the number of days taken to reach the Maximum Infected Value. This is reflected by right-ward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment, as well as a lower maxima value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Mortality rate is the percentage of deaths among all individuals who were previously infected. During the time of this research, there were 26 deaths in Malaysia out of a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. With a mortality rate of 1/9, it is difficult to calculate an accurate average due to the variation in this number across different demographics and its unpredictability. Additionally, the small number of COVID-19 deaths in Malaysia makes it unreliable to calculate an average mortality rate based on this limited sample size. Therefore, for analytical purposes, a mortality rate of 9 days is assumed.

In the Results and Discussion section, the study explores the impact of delaying the enforcement of mask-wearing using SEIR models in three scenarios. The models show that earlier enforcement of mask-wearing leads to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and delays the peak of infections. This is evident in Figure 3, which illustrates the differences in Maximum Infected Values based on the timing of mask enforcement in various scenarios. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. For the case of (a) 0 days of delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, and the peak occurs at day 291 after the first case was detected. For the case of a (b) 50 days delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, and the peak occurs on day 195.
post_context: and the peak occurs much earlier, on day 103. This scenario is nearly identical to the situation where there is no requirement for wearing masks in public, resulting in a peak infection rate of around 31.422%.

B117 strained virus has acquired the D614G spike protein mutation, reportedly increasing its infectivity, with little difference to its lethality [24]. According to studies done in Scotland, the
post_context: [25].In order to assess the impact of a delay in enforcing public mask usage on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers resulting from the B117 variant, we conducted a hypothetical scenario analysis. Assuming the first case of COVID-19 detected in Singapore is of the B117 variant, we adjusted our simulation to reflect the new R0 value associated with this variant. The resulting graphs are displayed in Figures 6 and 7, showing the Maximum Infection levels based on delay in mask enforcement for different scenarios. Our study differs from previous research by Eikenberry et al. [3] which focused on similar mathematical modelling in the US states of New York and Washington. Unlike their study, ours considers the specific context of Singapore, taking into account factors such as epidemiological parameters, size, and characteristics of the city-state. Additionally, our study incorporates newer, more infectious strains like the B117 variant and time-limited immunity, providing a more comprehensive analysis.

B117 strained virus has acquired the D614G spike protein mutation, reportedly increasing its infectivity, with little difference to its lethality [24]. According to studies done in the UK, the
original_post_context: [25]. To investigate the impact of delay in public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers due to the B117 variant, we modelled a hypothetical scenario. In this scenario, the first case of COVID-19 detected in Singapore is of the B117 variant. We ran our simulation of the 3 scenarios described in the preceding sections with a new value of R0 reflecting that of B117. The resulting plots are shown in Figure 6 and 7. Figure 6. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with full compliance and Scenario 3: SEIRS with time-limited immunity for the B117 variant case. Figure 7. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with gradual noncompliance for the B117 variant case. 6.3. Related Studies Juxtaposing our study against other similar studies that implement mathematical modelling on 'what-if' scenario based analysis, Eikenberry et al. [3] implemented a compartmentalized models for their simulations, and concluded that if the population remains unmasked until mask enforcement after some discrete delay, and that the level of adoption is fixed, the delay initially had little impact on the hospitalized fraction or deaths, but states that a 'point of no return' can be crossed. While this study yields similar results to ours, it is contextualised in the US states of New York and Washington, whilst ours was conducted in the context of Singapore. Given the differences in epidemiological parameters, size and characteristics of these cities and Singapore, our study adds value in being a more accurate representation of smaller city states. Furthermore, this study did not take into consideration newer, more infectious strains of the virus such as the B117 variant and time-limited immunity, which we have considered in our study.

The study was conducted at the Interdisciplinary Research Center for Mathematics and Life Sciences at Xi'an Jiaotong University in China, and the Laboratory for Industrial and Applied Mathematics at York University in Canada. The findings are crucial for implementing effective public health measures.School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Chengdu, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity. A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures. The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the
post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions implemented by Chengdu on infection rates in Beijing is comparable to a substantial increase in quarantine measures. It is crucial to evaluate the efficacy and duration of the costly measures implemented by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling the spread of 2019-nCoV. Under the strictest measures, it is predicted that the outbreak will peak within two weeks, with a significant decrease in peak value. Implementing travel restrictions, which prevent the entry of exposed individuals into Beijing, is projected to reduce the number of infections by 91.14% in seven days, compared to a scenario with no travel restrictions. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model. Introduction: Coronaviruses, classified as enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses within the Coronaviridae family, have caused several outbreaks with varying severity since their discovery in 1965. Notable outbreaks include SARS in 2003, MERS in 2012, and subsequent MERS outbreaks.

Sensitivity analyses show that interventions, such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation, can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk, with the effect of travel restriction adopted by Wuhan on 2019-nCoV infection in Beijing being almost equivalent to increasing quarantine by a 100 thousand baseline value. It is essential to assess how the expensive, resource-intensive measures implemented by the Chinese authorities can contribute to the prevention and control of the 2019-nCoV infection, and how long they should be maintained. Under the most restrictive measures, the outbreak is expected to peak within two weeks (since 23 January 2020) with a significant low peak value. With travel restriction (no imported exposed individuals to Beijing), the number of infected individuals in seven days will decrease by 91.14% in Beijing, compared with the scenario of no travel restriction. Introduction Coronaviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses belonging to the family of Coronaviridae [1]. They cause generally mild respiratory infections, even though they are occasionally lethal. Since their discovery and first characterization in 1965 [2], three major, large-scale outbreaks have occurred, caused by emerging, highly pathogenic coronaviruses, namely, the "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome" (SARS) outbreak in 2003 in mainland China [3], the "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome" (MERS) outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia [4,5] and the MERS outbreak in 2015 in South J. .As of January 10, 2020, two recovered patients were discharged from the hospital, resulting in an R(0) value of 2, with 739 individuals quarantined (Sq(0) = 739). We set H(0) = 1 to correspond to the confirmed case reported on the same day. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, giving a rate of λ = 1/14. The WHO states that the incubation period for 2019-nCoV is around 7 days, so σ = 1/7.

Likelihood-based estimates of Rc during the Shanghai outbreak show a mean value of 6.39 with a mean generation time of 6 days and a variance of 2 days based on a revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number ranges from 1.66 to 10 and is sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals. Another data series (dataRev2) gives a mean Rc value of 6.32 with a similar generation time. Both data series align well in estimating Rc, allowing them to be used to validate the proposed model in this study. We will use dataRev1 for fitting the model in subsequent sections of the manuscript.

As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set H(0) = 1, corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, thus λ = 1/14. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence σ = 1/7. 3. Results 3.1. Likelihood-Based Estimates Likelihood-based estimation of Rc during the outbreak in Wuhan gives a mean value of 6.39 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days on the basis of a revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number based on likelihood-based estimation ranges from 1.66 to 10 and it follows from Table 2 that Rc is sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals. Fitting to the other revised data series (dataRev2) gives a mean value of 6.32 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days. Note that the estimates of Rc based on the two time series agree well, and consequently, both revised data series can be used to fit the proposed dynamics transmission model. In this study, we chose the estimations based on dataRev1 as the comparison reference to verify and validate our model-based estimation. Thus, in the following sections of the manuscript, we will use the revised dataset (dataRev1) to fit the proposed model.

Fitting to the other revised data series (dataRev2) gives a mean value of 6.32 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days. Note that the estimates of Rc based on the two time series agree well, and consequently, both revised data series can be used to fit the proposed dynamics transmission model. In this study, we chose the estimations based on dataRev1 as the comparison reference to verify and validate our model-based estimation. Thus, in the following sections of the manuscript, we will use the revised dataset (dataRev1) to fit the proposed model.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
In our study, we utilized the likelihood-based method or generation interval-informed method developed by White and Pagano [23] for estimation. This method is represented by the formula L(Rc, p|N) = Σ t=1 exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1), where φt = Σ j=1 pjNt− j, and k is chosen as the maximum value of the serial interval (k = 6 in this case). The total number of cases on each day is denoted by N = {N0, N1, . . . , NT}, where T is the final day of observations. The probability function for the generation interval on each day is represented by pj. It is assumed that the generation interval follows a gamma distribution with mean E and variance V. To explore the sensitivity of Rc, the basic reproduction number, to different E values (ranging from 2 to 8 days), we conducted a detailed analysis as shown in Table 2. The data presented in Table 2 provides the estimation of the basic reproduction number for 2019-nCoV in Hubei, China based on different mean and deviation values of the gamma distribution.

Simulation The population of Hubei, China is around 11,081,000 inhabitants [18], hence, we set S(0) = 11, 081, 000. As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set
post_context: , corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The individuals in quarantine were kept separate for 14 days, resulting in a λ value of 1/14. The World Health Organization reports that the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is approximately 7 days, leading to a σ value of 1/7. Likelihood-based estimations of the reproduction number (Rc) in Hubei, China during the outbreak indicate a mean value of 6.39 with a mean and variance generation time of 6 and 2 days based on the data series (dataRev1). The range of Rc estimates is from 1.66 to 10, demonstrating sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals. Fitting to another revised data series (dataRev2) yields a mean value of 6.32 with the same generation time parameters. The agreement between estimates based on the two data series allows for the use of both in fitting the proposed transmission model. For comparison and validation purposes, we will use the estimates from the dataRev1 dataset as the basis for our model in the subsequent sections of the study.

Note that our estimation is based on a dataset collected during a period of intensive social contacts. Before the Chinese New Year (25 January 2020), there were lots of annual summing-up meetings and/or parties, with higher than usual close contacts, leading to a higher likelihood of infection transmission than that of the earlier periods covered by other studies. Furthermore, we noted that more recently published studies based on datasets during periods comparable with ours reported similar findings in terms of a high basic reproduction number (for instance, Reference [29], where authors, using an exponential growth method, computed a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16), assuming no changes in reporting rate and with a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days). Variability in the estimation of the basic reproduction number is also a well-known methodological issue, and standardized methods both for calculating and reporting it are still lacking [30]. During the initial phases of an epidemics outbreak, only small datasets/time-points can be used. Some crucial information may be missing, and the quality, accuracy and reliability of data improves over time. In these situations, estimations are highly dependent on the specific datasets utilized and revising/updating such datasets could influence the results. We note that several key clinical parameters could be inferred from relevant clinical data based on sero-epidemiological surveys, and the possibility of spreading the infection from asymptomatic cases was only reported recently [31]. author: enrique
pre_context: Using the exponential growth method, a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16) was calculated, assuming no changes in reporting rate with a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days. It is important to note that variability in estimating the basic reproduction number is a common methodological challenge, with standardized methods for calculation and reporting still lacking. Estimations during the early stages of an outbreak may be limited by small datasets and incomplete information. Data quality improves over time, and revising datasets can impact results. Key clinical parameters can be inferred from sero-epidemiological surveys, and the potential for transmission from asymptomatic cases has only recently been recognized. A high reproduction number suggests a serious epidemic unless prompt public health interventions are implemented, especially during times of high social contact. The serial interval plays a crucial role in estimating likelihood functions accurately. The incubation period for coronavirus pneumonia in Hubei, China patients is reported to be about 2 to 15 days. We then assume that the serial interval follows the gamma distribution with varying mean and variance, which allows us to examine the influence on the reproduction number. With the distribution of the serial interval with mean 6 days and a variance of 2 days, the likelihood-based estimation of the reproduction number is consistent with the model-based estimation. It shows that longer serial intervals induce greater reproduction numbers, and hence, more new infections, which further confirms that the epidemic may be more serious than what has been reported until now [15]. post_context: , as of 21 January 2020. The effort of close contact tracing and quarantine in Hubei, China was not enough to significantly decrease the number of infected cases or slow the spread of the epidemic. The threshold values of the contact rate and quarantine rate indicated in the R_c = 1 contour plot show that a city must have a high level of both to prevent an outbreak. Achieving this high level of quarantine requires a strong public health infrastructure and strict adherence to safety measures by citizens, such as reducing contact, separating, and staying restricted during quarantine. Maintaining such a high level of quarantine is only possible if there are very few imported cases from the epicenter, emphasizing the importance of travel restrictions. However, implementing strict travel restrictions to Hubei, China would be costly and challenging for decision-makers and the city's resilience, and would only serve to delay the spread of the infection.

The contour plot of R_c = 1 gives the threshold values of contact rate and quarantine rate for a city to avoid an outbreak. This high threshold rate of quarantine puts an extremely high requirement for the city's public health infrastructure and its citizens' adherence to personal protective and public health interventions, including a reduction of transmission-effective contacts, separation and restriction during the quarantine. Such a high level of quarantine rate and reduction of contact is possible only when the number of imported cases from the epicenter is minimal, speaking in terms of the value of the travel restriction. A strict travel restriction to the city of Wuhan is expensive and resource-consuming, imposing a substantial challenge to the decision- and policy-makers and the city's resilience. Moreover, such a measure could only delay the transmission of the infectious disorder.

Conclusions Coronaviruses occasionally lead to major outbreaks, with documented reproduction numbers ranging from 2.0 to 4.9. Currently, a fourth large-scale outbreak is occurring and spreading out from Wuhan, Hubei province, China, to neighboring provinces and other countries. There is a dearth of epidemiological data about the emerging coronavirus, which would be of crucial importance to design and implement timely, ad hoc effective public health interventions, such as contact tracing, quarantine and travel restrictions. In this study, we adopted a deterministic model to shed light on the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus and assess the impact of public health interventions on infection. We found that
original_post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23), which seems consistent with the special period prior to the Spring Festival when contacts were higher than usual, and with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations. It is worth mentioning that our model made a very good prediction of the confirmed cases from 23 to 29 January 2020, as shown in Table 4. Particularly, the predicted confirmed cases should be 7723 as of 29 January 2020, which is very close to the real number of cases of 7711. Furthermore, according to our model, the outbreak, under the most restrictive measures, is expected to peak within two weeks (since 23 January 2020), with a significant low peak value. Our investigation has major practical implications for public health decision- and policy-makers. The rather high reproduction number suggests that the outbreak may be more serious than what has been reported so far, given the particular season of increasing social contacts, warranting effective, strict public health measures aimed to mitigate the burden generated by the spreading of the new virus. author: enrique
pre_context:
Counties in Ohio with increased air transportation connectivity experienced a more rapid spread of COVID-19 compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. This geographical variation in the severity of the epidemic was not solely due to population distribution but also to spatial attributes like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in just five counties (Cleveland, Franklin County, Benjamin, Birmingham, and Mountaintop), with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties are densely populated and serve as local air hubs, receiving millions of passengers each year. The high connectivity and travelers in these counties can lead to a high influx of imported infections, accelerating local transmission and the spread of the virus.

In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context:
.

In contrast, only 7% of ICU beds in the state are located in rural and less connected counties, with a rate of 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite these disparities in healthcare capacity, our analysis suggests that the lower transmission rates in these areas prevented critical care saturation. If interventions were maintained, only 27% of state capacity would be reached, with three additional counties exceeding 50% capacity. However, easing interventions by 50% would result in 61% capacity reached, with areas of higher transmission saturating faster. Rural counties in Group 4 would experience slower saturation compared to Group 1, which would reach 94% capacity eight weeks after easing interventions.

Despite these local differences in the critical healthcare capacity of the state, our modeling results suggest that the differential local dynamics of the disease, with substantially  less  transmission  in  these  rural  and  less  connected counties, prevented the saturation of the critical care response in these areas.  We  found  that  if  the  non-pharmaceutical  interventions  implemented in the state in mid-March 2020 were maintained after early May, only 27% of the maximum critical care capacity of the state would be reached, and along with the 10 counties that do not have hospitals with ICU  beds.  Three  more  counties,  Clermont,  Delaware,  and  Lawrence would  reach  more  than  50%  of  their  maximum  critical  care  capacity under  this  scenario.  In  contrast,  our  predictions  indicated  that  if  the intervention is eased by 50%, an estimated 61% of the maximum critical healthcare capacity of the state would be reached eight weeks after the relaxation  of  the  intervention.  However,  areas  with  more  intense transmission of the disease (Group 1) would experience a faster saturation  of  the  critical  care  capacity.  Although  these  counties  had  the highest critical healthcare capacity, the faster and more intense spread of the epidemic experienced in these areas would substantially impact the critical care response in these counties. As a result, the healthcare capacity in these counties would be almost completely saturated (94% of the  maximum  capacity)  eight  weeks  after  the  social  distancing  intervention is eased. author: enrique
pre_context: The adjusted model indicated that variations in the severity of the COVID-19 epidemic across counties in Michigan were influenced not only by population distribution but also by factors like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were found in five counties (Cuyahoga, Franklin, Lucas, Montgomery, and Summit) with a high infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population densities and serve as local air hubs receiving millions of passengers annually. The airports in these counties contribute to the introduction of imported infections, accelerating the spread of the virus. In contrast, the spread of the infection was lower in rural and less connected counties in Michigan. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Michigan, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a rate of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a
post_context: . Even though there are variations in healthcare capacities among different areas of the state, our findings indicate that rural and less connected counties experienced lower transmission rates, preventing critical care services from becoming overwhelmed. If the state maintains non-pharmaceutical interventions introduced in mid-March 2020 beyond early May, only 27% of the maximum critical care capacity would be reached, with 10 counties lacking ICU beds. However, easing interventions by 50% could result in 61% capacity being reached after eight weeks, particularly in areas with higher disease transmission. Counties with more intense transmission would reach nearly full capacity (94%) in the same timeframe. On the other hand, less connected rural counties experienced slower spread of the infection, resulting in a lower impact on critical care services.

author: enrique
pre_context: We conducted a Bayesian analysis during the period and fall 2021 semester to analyze the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate. Using data from the 2021-2022 academic year and scientific literature on vaccine effectiveness against the Delta variant, we adjusted transmission rates by a factor of 2.5. Parameters were added to consider vaccine effectiveness on transmission and susceptibility to infection. Nearly 95% of Cornell students were vaccinated, with this percentage increasing as new international students received their vaccinations. Changes in social distancing restrictions, off-campus prevalence, contact tracing challenges, and quarantine requirements for asymptomatic vaccinated close contacts created uncertainty in various parameters. We employed a prior on these parameters, sampling and updating through simulations to form a posterior distribution. While there was uncertainty in individual parameters, the product of the first three showed more consistency in the posterior distribution, as depicted in Fig. 6A. Fall 2021 modeling. (A) Marginal posterior distribution for the key parameters. Vaccine susceptibility and vaccine transmission are multipliers on the probability of becoming infected given exposure and the probability of infecting, respectively, compared to interaction between an unvaccinated source and exposed individual. The contact rate multiplier,
post_context: , and contact tracing effectiveness parameters are all multipliers on the calibrated 2021-2022 parameters. Estimated median cumulative infections over the semester for different student vaccination levels, ranging from 50% to 100%, are compared with the average number of tests per student per week using a variety of effective testing strategies. This information is detailed in a study conducted by Frazier et al. titled "Modeling for COVID-19 college reopening decisions: Cornell, a case study" published in PNAS.
original_pre_context: eriod and later into the fall 2021 semester within a Bayesian analysis to understand the effect of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate. We additionally leveraged parameters calibrated to the 2020–2021 academic year data reported above, and information from the scientific literature on vaccine effectiveness and the transmission under the Delta variant. We began by elevating transmission rates in our model by a factor of 2.5 to account for the Delta variant. We added parameters to account for the effectiveness of vaccines against 1) transmission and 2) susceptibility to infection. We modeled 95% of the Cornell student population as vaccinated, a level that was later exceeded once newly arriving international students were vaccinated. Significant changes had occurred since previous semesters: Social distancing restrictions had been lifted, prevalence outside the campus had changed, contact tracing faced a larger number of contacts per trace (meaning less attention can be paid to each contact), and asymptomatic vaccinated close contacts were no longer required to quarantine. This created uncertainty in several parameters: transmission rates within and from outside campus, and the number of cases quarantined or isolated per initiated contact trace. We placed a (joint) prior on these parameters, sampled parameters from that prior, ran simulations at each parameter set, and updated the prior to a posterior; see Methods F and SI Appendix, section 4. author: enrique
pre_context: It is anticipated that approximately 680,000 people will have been infected by the end of 2021, with half of them being asymptomatic. The sharpest rise in cumulative infection curves occurred in December 2020 and March 2021, aligning with peaks in new case counts. By the end of 2021, it is projected that 71% of the Ontario population will have received at least one vaccine dose, with 57% fully vaccinated. COVID-related deaths are estimated to reach 11,000 by the year's end, with 36% from the wild-type strain, 47% from Alpha, and 17% from Delta. These predictions closely match reported data in Ontario. The drop in the susceptible population is notable after December 2020, largely due to vaccine distribution. By June 2021, only 37% of Ontarians are susceptible, with the majority having received one vaccine dose. The number of active infections peaked at the end of 2021 and again in spring, driven by the wild-type and Alpha variants. The Alpha-driven peak affected 0.7% of the population but decreased as vaccinations increased. Approximately half of infections were asymptomatic, with the majority of those infected being unvaccinated. The recovered population is projected to make up 7% of the total population by the end of 2021. These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. To identify the strongest determinants of the pandemic severity, we assess the sensitivity of model predictions to variations in key model parameters. We first conduct a sensitivity analysis in a simplified model that represents only the wild-type SARS-CoV-2, for the year 2021, but with

The cumulative infection curves exhibit the steepest rise in December 2020 and March 2021, corresponding to the two peaks in the new case counts. By the end of 2021, 71% of the Ontario population would have been vaccinated with at least one dose, with 57% fully vaccinated (Fig. 2c). At that time, 11 K would have died from COVID, with 36, 47, and 17% from wild type, Alpha, and Delta, respectively (Fig. 2d). The year-end infection and death statistics are within 10% of reported data in Ontario (750 K infections and 10.2 K deaths)16. Predicted population dynamics are shown in Fig. 3. The drop in the susceptible population becomes significant after December 2020 (Fig. 3a) and is driven primarily by the vaccine deployment. By the end of June 2021, only 37% of the Ontario population are susceptible, with the majority having received at least one dose of vaccine (Fig. 3b,c). The number of active infections peaks at the end of 2020, followed by an even higher peak at the end of spring (Fig. 3d). These are the wild-type and Alpha-driven waves identified in Fig. 2a and described above. The Alpha-driven infection peak accounts for 0.7% of the total population, but subsides as the vaccination effort accelerates. The infections are split approximately half-half between asymptomatic and symptomatic ones, with the majority unvaccinated (Fig. 3d–g). As the infection spreads, the recovered population also increases, to 7% of the population at the end of 2021 (Fig. 3h). These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. Parameters that are varied include those that describe the clinical features of the viruses as well as provincial policy and pharmaceutical intervention. Recall the baseline assumption that asymptomatic individuals are assumed to be more active and 3 times more likely to spread the disease than symptomatic ones (αW = 3). The effects of dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) are much smaller. Because dosing interval can vary greatly within the population, and because vaccine escape rate is not sufficiently well characterized, these two parameters were varied by 50%. The vaccine-related results suggest that among these three factors, an effective vaccine deployment (captured in ω1) is the key in combating a pandemic, and success may be achieved even by means of a less-than-ideal vaccine with higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Since the predicted numbers of infections and deaths are substantially more sensitive to variations in ω1 than ω2, if vaccine supply is limited, prioritizing the first dose by lengthening the dosing interval would be advisable, as was done in Canada. author: chunwei
pre_context: Figure 2 displays data on new infections for different viruses, represented as 7-day averages from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021. Additionally, it includes cumulative asymptomatic and symptomatic infections, the percentage of the population vaccinated with at least one or both doses, and cumulative deaths from the viruses. Even small variations in these parameters (5%) can have a significant impact on infection and mortality rates, as shown in Fig. 4. The COVID-19 mortality rate affects the number of infected individuals who are still alive and capable of spreading the disease. Because the COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS-CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ),
post_context: delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2, PZ and ω2, AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). λ and ω1 are adjusted by 5%, which has a significant impact on model predictions for NPI (Fig. 4). The rate of vaccination also influences the spread of the disease, although to a lesser extent. In contrast, the dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) have smaller effects. These parameters were varied by 50% due to the wide variability of dosing intervals in the population and the lack of detailed information on vaccine escape rates. The findings related to vaccines indicate that effective deployment of the vaccine (captured in ω1) is crucial in fighting a pandemic, suggesting that success can be achieved even with a less optimal vaccine that has a higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Given that variations in ω1 impact predicted infections and deaths more significantly than ω2, if vaccine supply is limited, it may be wise to prioritize the first dose by extending the dosing interval, as seen in Canada. In a secondary sensitivity analysis, we used the full model incorporating all three variants with baseline parameter values (Table S1). Key parameters were increased to assess their impact on infection and death rates associated with each variant. In addition to the parameters previously discussed, we also considered parameters related to VOC interactions: βX R, the rate of infection for individuals with partial immunity from a different variant, and ηR, the rate of immunity loss due to infection. These parameters have different values for each variant. Simulations were carried out by independently adjusting the values of each parameter for individual variants. Specifically, βX (X = W, A, or D), σX, αX, γX, and ω1 were increased by 5%, λ by 10%, and μI, βX R was increased fourfold to assess the impact on V, and ω2 by 50%.

The vaccine-related results suggest that among these three factors, an effective vaccine deployment (captured in ω1) is the key in combating a pandemic, and success may be achieved even by means of a less-than-ideal vaccine with higher escape rate (Fig. 4). author: enrique
pre_context: Figure 5 illustrates the impact of increasing model parameter values on total infections and deaths in a two-year simulation involving the dynamics of different virus variants. Parameters are adjusted individually for the wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants. Changes in infection and mortality rates are then calculated for each variant. The parameters examined include virus infectivity, rate of infection of recovered individuals from another variant, ratio of asymptomatic versus symptomatic infections, infectivity of asymptomatic versus symptomatic individuals, mortality rate, recovery rate, loss of immunity rate, vaccine escape rate, NPI stringency, dosing interval, and vaccination rate. The baseline model assumes a distribution of 95% Pfizer and 5% AstraZeneca vaccines, similar to vaccination statistics in Ontario. Consideration is given to the impact of a higher proportion of AstraZeneca vaccines, as seen in the UK, where Pfizer is found to provide better protection against all variants, particularly Delta, with either one or two doses. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By December 31, 2021, the model predicts
post_context:
, more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day.

The number of Delta infections and related deaths is projected to increase significantly by December 31, 2021, reaching 62K and 882, respectively, compared to the initial values of 39K and 689. If the vaccination rate in the province is lower, with only 67% of the population receiving at least one dose by September 1, 2021, compared to the initial rate of 74%, the total number of infections and deaths could rise by 75% by March 2022; refer to Fig. 7b,d. Ontario began reopening gradually in mid-June 2021, with plans to resume in-person classes in September. The baseline model assumes that the remaining non-pharmaceutical interventions would still reduce COVID-19 spread by 60%. However, considering the possibility of pandemic fatigue, desire for personal interactions, and potential outbreaks in schools, we analyze a scenario with less strict interventions from the fall of 2021 (September 1, 2021), with the λ value increased from its baseline of 0.4.

author: enrique
pre_context: The sensitivity of model predictions to increases in parameter values was assessed in a two-year simulation involving variant dynamics. Parameters were adjusted individually for the wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants, leading to relative changes in infections and deaths. Key parameters examined included virus infectivity, rate of infection from recovered individuals, ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic infections, and mortality and recovery rates. Additionally, the impact of vaccine type and distribution, particularly between Pfizer and AstraZeneca, was considered. Notably, the Pfizer vaccine offers greater protection against all variants, including Delta, compared to AstraZeneca. In Ontario, where 95% of vaccines are Pfizer and 5% are AstraZeneca, the implications of a higher proportion of AstraZeneca vaccines, as seen in the UK, were discussed.We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By December 31, 2021, the model predicts 794 new Delta infections a day, more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a). The total
post_context: at December 31, 2021, respectively, compared to baseline values of 39 K and 689 (Fig. 7b,d).If the provincial vaccination rate were to decrease, causing only 67% of the population to be vaccinated with at least one dose by September 1, 2021, compared to the original baseline vaccination rate of 74% (Fig. 7c), the total number of Delta infections and deaths would rise by 75% by the end of March 2022, as shown in Fig. 7b,d. Ontario began a phased reopening in mid-June 2021, with in-person classes scheduled to resume in September. The baseline model assumes that the non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI) still in place will reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. However, what if this assumption is too optimistic? Pandemic fatigue and a desire for personal interactions may lead to less stringent adherence to NPI, especially with potential outbreaks in schools. Therefore, we consider a scenario with reduced NPI effectiveness starting in the fall of 2021 (September 1, 2021), with λ increased from the original value of 0.4 (Scientific Reports, 2022).

Since January 23rd, 2020, there have been significant changes in the parameters of control strategies, specifically in the contact rate, diagnose rate, and quarantined rate q. To account for this, we kept all parameter values constant except for those three, which were estimated in our previous study (Tang et al., 2020). The initial contact rate c0 was determined to be 14.781 based on the average contact rate between January 10th, 2020 and January 22nd, 2020, while dI0 was set at 0.133 using the same assumption. By solving our previous model from January 10th, 2020 to January 23rd, 2020, we obtained the initial conditions. The key objective now is to estimate the parameter values q; cb along with r1; dIf ; r2. To achieve this, we utilized the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method and employed an adaptive Metropolis-Hastings algorithm with 70,000 iterations and a burn-in of the first 50,000 iterations, ensuring convergence with the Geweke diagnostic method. The estimation results are shown in Table 1.

Due to the lockdown of Hubei on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions have been implemented across the country and advancements in detection technologies have led to faster case confirmations. With China's aggressive prevention and control measures and enhanced detection and treatment capabilities, the previously estimated basic reproduction number may no longer accurately reflect the epidemic's trajectory in the near future. Therefore, we use the updated data to parameterize the proposed model (Tang et al., 2020) and re-estimate the 2019-nCov transmission risk. To estimate the effective daily reproduction ratio, we initially get the time-dependent contact rate cðtÞ and dIðtÞ as Fig. 1(a). author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study by Tang and colleagues (2020), a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71-7.23) was estimated, which is higher compared to previous calculations. The World Health Organization (WHO) reported a reproduction number of 1.4-2.5, while Li et al. (2020) found a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4-3.9). Various other mathematical models have suggested reproduction numbers ranging from 1.3 to 4.7. Additionally, Zhao et al. (2020) and Read et al. (2020) have identified potential underestimations of coronavirus cases in their studies. Zhao et al. (2020) used a quantitative approach to assess under-reporting, estimating 469 unreported cases (95% CI 403-540) and a basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49-2.63). A previous version of their study suggested a reproductive number between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73-3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16-7.10). The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an ascertainment rate of 5.0% (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Hubei there were
post_context: , and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. The calculated basic reproduction number is 3.11 (95% CI 2.39-4.13), suggesting that at least 58-76% of transmissions need to be blocked to halt the outbreak. Three additional models, including those by Imai et al. (2020), Kucharski et al. (2020), and Wu et al. (2020), integrate data on international travel. Imai et al. (2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5-3.5) with variations ranging from 1.9 to 4.2 based on different scenarios and levels of exposure. The reproduction number ranged from 1.3 to 2.7 based on different estimates of generation time. Control measure predictions in Fig. 2 show the impact of changing contact rates and susceptible population sizes after January 29th, 2020.

Within the existing literature, two studies estimated under-estimation of coronavirus cases: the investigations by Zhao and collaborators (Zhao et al., 2020) and by Read et al. (Read, Bridgen, Cummings, Ho, & Jewell, 2020). Specifically, Zhao and coworkers (Zhao et al., 2020) have assessed from a quantitative standpoint the under-reporting rate of coronavirus cases, modeling the epidemic growth curve using the exponential growing Poisson process. In a previous version of the investigation, released in the bioRxiv pre-print server, the reproduction number was computed to oscillate between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10). author: enrique
pre_context: The reproduction number for the coronavirus, as estimated in various studies, has been found to range from 1.3 to 7.23. While the WHO estimated a range of 1.4 to 2.5, Li et al. calculated a slightly higher value of 2.2. Other mathematical models have shown a range from 1.3 to 4.7. Some studies have also highlighted the underestimation of coronavirus cases, with Zhao et al. estimating 469 underreported cases and a reproduction number of 2.56. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Different studies have calculated varying estimates of the reproduction number of COVID-19. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimated a value of 1.4e2.5, while Li et al. found it to be slightly higher at 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9). Other mathematical models have reported reproduction numbers ranging from 1.3 to 4.7. Two studies, by Zhao et al. and Read et al., have highlighted the underestimation of coronavirus cases. Zhao et al. quantitatively assessed the under-reporting rate, determining 469 cases (95% CI 403e540) were not reported. This led to a calculated basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). The investigation also found variations in the reproduction number, with a range of 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) to 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10) in a previous version of the study. The basic reproduction number was linked to an increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an ascertainment rate of 5.0% (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Nanjing there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. The

The reproduction number also fluctuated from 1.3 to 2.7 to 1.7-4.3 based on different estimates of generation time. The reproduction number fluctuated between 1.6 and 2.9, indicating varying levels of infectiousness. It was assumed that the novel virus would result in more mild-to-moderate cases compared to SARS, resulting in a reproduction number of 2.0 (with uncertainty ranging from 1.4 to 2.3). The study concluded that public health interventions needed to block over 60% of transmission to effectively control and contain the coronavirus outbreak. Different studies, including those by Imai et al. and Yu, have estimated varying reproduction numbers and quarantine rates necessary to control the outbreak. Kucharski and colleagues utilized a stochastic SEIR model with a time-varying reproduction number estimated using the sequential Monte-Carlo approach, providing real-time estimates while overcoming data reliability issues.Transmission was modeled as a random process, fluctuating and varying over the time. Similar to the model of Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020), the risk of transmission and the risk of causing a large outbreak were modeled based on a negative binomial offspring distribution, with incubation and infectious period being Erlang distributed. Median reproduction number was found to oscillate between 1.6 and 2.9 before the introduction and implementation of travel restriction. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020. Based on these estimates, the pandemics outbreak is expected to significantly decrease within 77 [95% CI 75e80] days from its beginning. Furthermore, authors found that every one-day reduction in the duration of the period from illness/symptom onset to isolation would reduce the peak population size by 72e84% and the cumulative infected cases and deaths both by 68e80%. The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Controlling and containing the coronavirus outbreak would greatly benefit from a high percentage of transmission control measures. Research by Imai and colleagues (Imai et al., 2020) and Yu (Yu, 2020) has shown that a basic reproduction number of 3.5 indicates a need for a quarantine rate of over 90% of the infectious population to effectively manage the outbreak. Kucharski and team (Kucharski et al., 2020) developed a stochastic SEIR model with a time-varying reproduction number to provide real-time estimates. Utilizing various datasets and the Poisson probability calculation, they modeled transmission as a fluctuating process, with risks of transmission and causing a large outbreak based on a negative binomial distribution. The median reproduction number ranged from 1.6 to 2.9 before travel restrictions were implemented, similar to the findings of Imai et al. (2020).The study by Wu and collaborators (Wu et al., 2020), based on nowcasting and forecasting approach, estimated a basic reproductive number of 2.68 (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Wuhan as of January 25th, 2020. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to
post_context: (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020.Based on these projections, it is anticipated that the pandemic outbreak will significantly decrease within approximately 77 days (95% CI 75-80) from its onset. Researchers also observed that a one-day decrease in the time from illness/symptom onset to isolation could lead to a substantial decrease in peak population size by 72-84% and cumulative infected cases and deaths by 68-80%. Different studies by various authors estimated the reproduction number to range from 2.0-3.8, using different models and statistical techniques. These variations in findings may be attributed to methodological differences, such as assumptions, model types, datasets, and estimation periods. Additionally, the reproduction number was found to fluctuate over time, reflecting the changing dynamics of the coronavirus outbreak and case reporting.

prior_outline: 3.2 Local stability in terms of the basic reproduction number
text: β (cid:3) Transmission coefficient due to super-spreaders 7.65 day −1
author: chunwei
pre_context: F. Ndaïrou, I.Area and J.J. Nieto et al. / Chaos, Solitons and Fractals 135 (2020) 109846 3 Table 1 Values of the model parameters corresponding to the situation of Hubei, as discussed in Section 5, for which R 0 = 0 . 945. Name Description β l
post_context: day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0 is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1, precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h) ρ2. The basic reproduction number R0 calculated from the parameters used in our simulations (refer to Table 1) is 0.945, indicating that the Chinese authorities effectively controlled the epidemic outbreak in Hubei. Local stability in relation to the basic reproduction number can be studied by analyzing the remaining coupled system of state variables E, I, P, and H in the model. The Jacobian matrix associated with these variables forms the basis for this analysis. Additionally, since the total population size N is constant, the equation S(t) = N - [E(t) + I(t) + P(t) + A(t) + H(t) + R(t) + F(t)] is derived. The eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix are determined through a characteristic polynomial, providing insight into the local stability of the model.

post_context: 0.580 0.001 0.94 0.27 0.5 3.5 1 0.3 Units day −1 dimensionless day −1 day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0  is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1 , precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h ) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h ) ρ2 .Using the parameters from Table 1 in our simulations, the calculated basic reproduction number is R0 = 0.945. post_context: 0.001 0.94 0.27 0.5 3.5 1 0.3 Units day −1 dimensionless day −1 day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0  is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1 , precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h ) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h ) ρ2 .The parameters used in our simulations result in a basic reproduction number of R0 = 0.945, indicating effective control of the epidemic outbreak in Hankou by Chinese authorities. The local stability in terms of the basic reproduction number can be analyzed by considering the remaining system equations of variables E, I, P, and H. The Jacobian matrix associated with these variables is given by J M = β [ -κ, κρ1, κρ2, 0; κ, -γa, 0, 0; 0, β, -(γa+h), 0; 0, 0, γa, -γh ]. The eigenvalues of this matrix can be determined by solving the characteristic polynomial Z(λ) = λ^4 + a1λ^3 + a2λ^2 + a1λ + a4, where the coefficients a1, a2, a3, and a4 are specified in the equations.
