text: ρ 2 Rate at which exposed people become super-spreaders 0.001
author: chunwei
pre_context: F. Ndaïrou, I.Area and J.J. Nieto et al. / Chaos, Solitons and Fractals 135 (2020) 109846 3 Table 1 Values of the model parameters corresponding to the situation of Hubei, as discussed in Section 5 , for which R 0 = 0 . 945 . Name Description β l β (cid:3) κ ρ 1
post_context: 0.94 0.27 0.5 3.5 1 0.3 Units day −1 dimensionless day −1 day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0  is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1 , precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h ) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h ) ρ2 .Based on the parameters used in our simulations (refer to Table 1), the calculated basic reproduction number is R0 = 0.945. This suggests that the outbreak of the epidemic in Hubei was effectively controlled by the Chinese authorities. Regarding local stability in relation to the basic reproduction number, we note that certain equations in the system are not interconnected with the rest of the equations, allowing us to derive analytical results through direct integration. Given that the total population size remains constant, the local stability of the model can be analyzed by studying the remaining system of interconnected state variables: E, I, P, and H in (1). The Jacobian matrix associated with these variables is presented as follows: JM = β [ -κ, κρ1, κρ2, 0; γa, 0, 0, δp; 0, γa, -δh, 0; 0, 0, δi, -δp ]. The eigenvalues of JM can be obtained by solving the characteristic polynomial, where the coefficients are defined in (3).

author: PGAHAN

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The pathogen present in the environment is labeled as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, N(t) equals S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has shown that COVID-19 can be spread through human-to-human contact as well as from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t) individuals infected with the virus can transmit it to susceptible persons (S(t)) they come into close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals sneeze or cough without precautions, the virus can spread to the environment, where it can remain for days, exposing susceptible individuals to pathogens, particularly in the early stages of the outbreak. This leads susceptible individuals to the exposed population (E(t)), who then may become asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) individuals. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens during human interaction at time t. Recovered individuals move to R(t) after infection. The interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment is illustrated in Fig. 1, with model parameters detailed in Table 1. The COVID-19 transmission model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations, as shown in Fig. 1: SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission.

The study developed a mathematical model to analyze the spread and transmission of SARS-CoV-2. This model divides the human population into different categories such as susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals, while also considering the presence of the virus in the environment. Research indicates that the virus can spread through human-to-human contact as well as from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic and symptomatic, can transmit the virus to susceptible individuals they come into close contact with. Additionally, virus transmission can occur when infected individuals sneeze or cough without taking necessary precautions, spreading the virus into their surroundings.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. The model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations, as shown in the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission in Figure 1. This model showcases the compartments for humans (SEIR, colored in yellow) and pathogens (P, colored in green).

prior_outline: Fig. 2 Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model.
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Figure 2 displays the dynamics of shield immunity in a SIR model. Panel a shows the infectious case dynamics with varying levels of shielding, denoted as α. Panel b illustrates the final state of the system based on α, with a transmission rate (β) of 0.25 and a recovery rate (γ) of 0.1. To effectively incorporate interactions with hospitalized patients, specific implementation scenarios with healthcare workers are essential. The baseline epidemiological parameters, age-stratified risk, and population structure can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2 and in the provided code on GitHub. Our simulations begin with a single exposed individual leading to an outbreak until it reaches 0.1% total prevalence, at which point a shielding strategy is introduced. Various outbreak scenarios with different transmission rates are considered. Early estimates from Wuhan suggest a transmission rate within a confidence interval of 2.1 to 4.5.30), putting our high-transmission scenario on the conservative end of estimated ranges. However, the of the high-transmission scenario we examine here is consistent with the range of 2.0–2.6 considered in ref. 5, and with the median of (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as R0 ¼ I estimated via stochastic model fits to outbreak data in North Korea that account for undocumented transmission28. Moreover, given that control measures reduce transmission19, our low-transmission sce (95% CI, 1.14–1.63) nario is consistent with estimates of in North Korea from 24 January to 3 February after travel restrictions
post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented. The results displayed in Figure 3 compare the impact of shielding interventions on epidemic outcomes to a baseline scenario. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the overall burden of the epidemic by decreasing the total number of cases and shortening the peak. In a high-transmission setting with a population of 10,000,000, the model predicts 71,000 deaths without shielding, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). In a low-transmission scenario with the same population size, the model projects 50,000 deaths without shielding, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Despite fewer individuals in older age groups, most deaths occur in those age ranges, consistent with other COVID-19 models and experiences in Italy and North Korea. The simulation focuses on the impact of shielding alone, while acknowledging that ongoing measures such as social distancing and shelter-in-place orders also play a role in reducing interactions. The effectiveness of shielding depends on factors such as the number and substitutability of identified shields (αRshields) and varies based on demographic distributions, asymptomatic transmission rates, and immunity duration. Populations with a higher proportion of older individuals may benefit more from shielding. While there are fewer recovered individuals in certain age groups, the potential benefits of shielding remain significant.

original_post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented. Figure 3 shows the results of comparing shielding interventions to the baseline outbreak. As in  the  simple  SIR  model,  shielding  on  its  own  could  potentially decrease epidemic burden across multiple metrics, decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of size  10,000,000  for  the  high-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions are 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared with 58,000 deaths given intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths  given  enhanced  shielding  (α = 20).  In  a  population  of  size 10,000,000  for  the  low-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions from our model are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case compared  with  34,000  deaths  given  intermediate  shielding  and 8,300 deaths given enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths are of individuals aged 60 years and older, despite the lower fraction of individuals  in  those  ranges  (Fig.  3),  which  is  consistent  with  estimates in related COVID-19 models5,27,28 and from the outbreaks in Italy and China31. Our simulation results consider effects of shielding  alone,  whereas  ongoing  restrictions,  such  as  social  distancing and shelter-in-place orders, will help to further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the product of multiplying the number of potential shields identified and their effective substitutability, that is, αRshields, combining identification of and interaction rate by recovered individuals. The population-scale effects of shielding relies on multiple factors,  including  demographic  distributions,  the  fraction  of  asymptomatic transmission26,28 and the duration of immunity. We find that populations with a strongly right-shifted demographic distribution could  potentially  receive  increased  benefits  from  shielding. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In a study published in 2020, researchers examined the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The coronavirus disease has been spreading rapidly in China and in more than 30 countries within the last two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in observing the real dynamics versus daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on intervention effectiveness.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context:
), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, it is predicted that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Hunan by late March, in the rest of China by mid-March, and in the tier-one cities before early March 2020. In total, it is estimated that 80,511 individuals are infected in China, with the majority in Wuhan, followed by Hunan and other regions. These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and come with some uncertainty.

It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. The model used can also assist in predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other countries at risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The characteristics of COVID-19, including high infectivity during incubation and time delays in reporting cases, make it unique and require tailored intervention strategies. The SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of the disease and can be beneficial in forecasting and planning interventions globally.
original_pre_context: y 2020, 8(1): 11–19 https://doi.org/10.1007/s40484-020-0199-0 RESEARCH ARTICLE Modeling the epidemic dynamics and control of COVID-19 outbreak in China Shilei Zhao1,2,3, Hua Chen1,2,3,4,* 1 CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101, China 2 China National Center for Bioinformation, Beijing 100101, China 3 School of Future Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China 4 CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Kunming 650223, China * Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn Received February 29, 2020; Revised March 4, 2020; Accepted March 4, 2020 Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over last two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of China. original_post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. Summary:
The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in India and numerous other countries in recent months. This disease presents unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and reported daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on its spread.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), India (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of India excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.As of February 12, 2020, there were 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 may end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, in India excluding Hubei by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March. In India, a total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of India (excluding Hubei). These estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and carry some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hubei until late March. This model can be helpful in predicting the spread of the epidemic and providing guidance for countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in India and over 30 countries in the last two months, exhibiting unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation and intervention effects of quarantine measures. The SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, using daily data from India to forecast the epidemic trend and offer guidance to other countries facing a high risk of outbreak.

author: PGAHAN

chenh@big.ac.cn Date of Receipt: February 29, 2020; Date of Revision: March 4, 2020; Date of Acceptance: March 4, 2020

The rapid spread of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in China and more than 30 countries over the past two months has raised concerns due to its unique characteristics. These characteristics include high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures.

A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly account for the impact of control measures. This model is more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Using the SUQC model, the daily confirmed infection data was analyzed for the outbreak of COVID-19 in Chongqing, Hubei (excluding Chongqing), China (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities of China. Results show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Chongqing estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Chongqing (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chongqing on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Chongqing and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Chongqing, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Chongqing), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and come with some level of uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen before early March, and in Hubei before late March. This model can be used to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in China and numerous other countries. It exhibits unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed case numbers, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and is being applied to China's daily data to predict the course of the epidemic. This model can also offer valuable guidance to countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. Copyright © 2020 Higher Education Press. pre_context: Received on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020 Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries in the last two months. COVID-19 exhibits unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in the observed number of confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We have developed a model called Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, explicitly taking into account the effects of intervention measures. This model is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model has been applied to the daily data of confirmed infections to study the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan), and four major cities in China. Our analysis shows that, until January 30, 2020, all regions, except Beijing, had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that quarantine and control measures have been effective in mitigating the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid-March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some degree of uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. This model can also be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. A SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 using data from China and can be used to predict the course of the epidemic and provide guidance for other high-risk countries. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in India and more than 30 other countries over the past two months. This disease stands out from others due to its high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between real dynamics and daily reported confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on its spread. To better understand the dynamics of COVID-19, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model. This model explicitly incorporates the effects of intervention measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to other epidemic models. By applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we were able to analyze the outbreak in various regions of India. Our findings show that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Delhi had a reproductive number (R) above 1. However, after January 30, all regions had an R value below 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in containing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Mumbai estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Maharashtra excluding Mumbai (0.1914), and that of India excluding Maharashtra (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Mumbai on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Mumbai and Maharashtra is around late March, around mid March for India excluding Maharashtra, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, among which 49,510 are from Mumbai, 17,679 from Maharashtra (excluding Mumbai), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of India (excluding Maharashtra). The estimates from a deterministic ODE model may have some uncertainty. It is recommended to continue rigorous quarantine and control measures in Delhi, Kolkata, Chennai, and Bengaluru until early March, and in Maharashtra until late March. This model can be used to predict the epidemic trend and provide guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The rapid spread of COVID-19 in India and more than 30 countries in the past two months highlights its unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures. A SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, using data from India to predict the epidemic trend and offer guidance for other countries at risk of an outbreak. text: The total number of infected individuals is estimated to be 49,510
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In Figure 1B, there is a noticeable discrepancy between the predicted total infections and confirmed infections in Hubei. Hubei's local medical agency implemented clinical diagnosis as an additional criterion after February 14, resulting in increased confirmation rates and a rise in confirmed infections. Despite clinical diagnosis, a portion of the total infected population remains unidentified. Using the inferred parameters, we projected long-term predictions for total infected individuals, unquarantined infected individuals, quarantined infected individuals, and cumulative confirmed infections in Hubei (Figure 1A). The endpoint is estimated to be 147 days from Jan 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Analyzing stage I data from Hubei, which assumes no strict quarantine or control measures, we used the first 10 daily data points from Jan 20 to infer parameters, while the remaining data was used to test the model's performance (Figure 1C, D). As shown in Figure 1C, the predicted numbers of confirmed and total infections increase significantly, surpassing the observed numbers after Jan 21. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Hubei and clinical diagnosis was adopted after February 14, we also analyzed the stage III data. The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.
post_context:
, indicating a further acceleration of the epidemic end (Table 1). An analysis was conducted on stage I and II data of Hubei province (excluding Hubei), the entire country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China. The model's predictions were highly accurate in these regions, showing distinct differences in predicted infection numbers between the two stages of data, highlighting the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. It was observed that even with stage I data, Beijing exhibited a reproductive number below 1, indicating a prompt and efficient response to COVID-19 at an early stage.

Analysis of the data revealed that Hubei had the largest difference between confirmed and infected numbers, with the city exceeding the clinical resources capacity and experiencing a low confirmation rate. However, after implementing clinical diagnosis in Hubei on February 14, the confirmation rate increased significantly. The model predicted that by February 11, 2020, there were 26,810 unconfirmed infections in Hubei.

Furthermore, examination of the quarantine rate and reproductive number in Hubei, Hubei (excluding Hubei), and China (excluding Hubei) showed varying results at different stages of the epidemic, emphasizing the impact of control measures and healthcare resources on the outbreak dynamics.

Clinical diagnosis is adopted by Wuhan local medical agency as an additional diagnosis criterion after Feb 12, increasing the confirmation rate and causing a big boost of the number of confirmed infections. Note that a proportion of the total infected still remains unidentified even with clinical diagnosis. With the inferred parameters, we further plot the longterm predictions of the numbers of total infected (I), unquarantined infected (U ), quarantined infected (Q) and cumulative confirmed infections (C) in Wuhan (Fig. 1A). The end time (increment of confirmed infections equals zero) is predicted to be 147 days from Jan 28, 2020. The total number of infected individuals is 62,577 (Table 1). The first 10 daily data points (from Jan 20) were used to infer the parameters. The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). compared to the other six regions (all close to or larger than 0.5).This results in a higher reproductive number (R=α=g1). The reproductive number in Nanjing decreases from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III, indicating that the epidemic in China is largely under control. However, un-quarantined individuals continue to pose a risk for new infections. Using data from stage II, it is estimated that there are still 3,509 individuals in Nanjing as of Feb 12 (Fig.1A), with person-to-person transmission expected to continue until mid-May 2020. With data from stage III, the quarantine rate in Nanjing increases to 0.6185 and the number of unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 on Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E).
Predictions made after analyzing data from stages II and III suggest that the epidemic in Nanjing and Hubei (excluding Nanjing) will end around late-March, while the whole of China is predicted to see an end around mid-March. The four first-tier cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen) are expected to see an end to the epidemic before early March. The criteria for the end time of the epidemic differ, with the end time based on zero un-quarantined infections usually being earlier than that based on zero new confirmed infections.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
The consideration of uncertainties in data is crucial in modeling, as it allows for each time point's data to follow a probability distribution based on the assumed model's mean and variance. This variance may be dependent on the mean, highlighting the importance of understanding the relationship between available data, such as confirmed cases, and model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who have been tested and received a positive result for COVID-19, while the infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms or testing status. This discrepancy between confirmed cases and total infected population can be likened to an iceberg, with confirmed cases representing the visible tip above the surface, while the hidden population beneath the water symbolizes those unknown to public health surveillance and testing, often referred to as the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirmed cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 1789e1790, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 1790).

Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model, it is necessary to adjust the transmission rate b by the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed case data. This process allows for the estimation of key model parameters and the basic reproduction number R0, determining the scale and peak time of the epidemic. However, the wide range of potential values for the case-infection ratio r in relation to the transmission rate b can lead to a wide range of model predictions, known as nonidentifiability. This issue arises when different combinations of parameter values can yield similar fits to the data, resulting in significantly different predictions. Addressing nonidentifiability in the model calibration process is crucial for improving the reliability of model predictions. Traditional methods like nonlinear least squares may not effectively detect or resolve this issue, as they rely on basic optimization algorithms that may struggle to find the global minimum of the objective function. As a result, developing more sophisticated approaches to address nonidentifiability is essential for enhancing the accuracy of model predictions.
original_pre_context: already take into consideration uncertainties in data by allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean given by the assumed model and the variance t given by the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may depend on the mean. The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. A key issue that can explain the variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) compares with model predictions. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. The part of the iceberg hidden under the water represents the infected people that are unknown to public health surveillance and testing; often called the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019e2020, the
original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, China, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hubei, China, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. The SEIR model includes a latent compartment E to represent individuals infected but not yet infectious, reflecting the realistic biology of COVID-19 with a potential 14-day incubation period. It is important to distinguish between the latent period (time from infection to infectiousness) and the incubation period (time from infection to symptom onset). While SARS individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear, COVID-19 evidence suggests individuals can be infectious before symptoms show. The SEIR model is more biologically accurate but requires parameters for latent period and initial latent population. Diagrams and parameter meanings are in Tables 1 and 2. Assumptions exclude deaths in S, E, and I compartments during modeling, with death data not affecting model fitting using confirmed case data. The differential equations for both models are outlined.

The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Wuhan, compartment
original_post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is added to denote the individuals who are infected but not infectious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are shown in Fig. 1. The biological meaning of all model parameters are given in Table 1 and Table 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. (4 months). Since we use the newly confirmed case data for model calibration, which is matched to the rI term in both models, the death term in the R compartment has no effect on our model fitting. post_context: .In the SEIR model, a latent compartment (E) represents infected individuals who are not yet infectious. The latency of COVID-19 is biologically realistic due to a potential 14-day incubation period, during which newly infected individuals may not be contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to being infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of symptoms like fever and coughing. Unlike SARS, where infectiousness typically begins two days after symptom onset, evidence suggests that COVID-19 individuals can be contagious before showing symptoms. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, but it requires additional unknown parameters such as the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the susceptible, exposed, and infected compartments are negligible. Model parameters are detailed in Tables 1 and 2, and the system of differential equations for each model is provided. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. pre_context: Our baseline predictions for Chengdu consist of prediction intervals generated by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals derived from Bayesian inference using newly confirmed cases in Chengdu from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These projections reflect the situation in Chengdu during the lockdown and travel restrictions before additional control measures were implemented on February 7, 2020. The projections offer an estimation of the potential epidemic in Chengdu if further control measures were not put in place after February 7. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Chengdu together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.

original_pre_context: nical, surveillance, or administrative data, and from published literature, that can be used for model calibration. This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.

If a realistic network structure (including households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is considered, the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. The default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values were chosen to maintain a relative weighting of 10:2:2:1, aligning with time-use surveys and previous studies on infections with known contact types. In a typical transmission scenario without interventions, around 30% of transmission events occur through households, 25% through workplaces, 15% through schools, and 30% through the community. The value of β can be adjusted through interventions like physical distancing. We also account for variations in individual infectiousness by allowing differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape

The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a specific day. Viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values are illustrated in Fig 2. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary based on the situation; estimated distributions for Seattle are referenced in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced if the infected individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our initial assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted as necessary for different modeling scenarios or contexts, recognizing that some studies have suggested lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].

The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below.
